The "Health Savings Account Expansion Act of 2009" repeals the high deductible health plan requirement and allows health insurance to be purchased from the account. It also increases the dollar limitation and terminates existing health-related tax preferences for medical coverage and employer deductions for health coverage. Section 223 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deductions for cash payments to a health savings account. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust dollar amounts in various sections related to health savings accounts. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust dollar amounts in various sections related to health savings accounts, including changes to sections 106(d)(1), 408(d)(9), 877A(g)(6), and 4973(g). Section 4973(g) is further amended by updating references from section 223(d) to section 223(c), section 223(f)(2) to section 223(e)(2), and section 223(f)(3) to section 223(e)(3). Section 4975 is also amended to update references from section 223(d) to section 223(c) and section 223(e)(2) to section 223(d)(2), as well as in subsection (e)(1)(E). Additionally, section 6693(a)(2)(C) is amended in such Code. Section 6693(a)(2)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by replacing "section 223(h)" with "section 223(g)". SEC. 102 amends the definition of 'qualified medical expenses' in the Internal Revenue Code to include amounts paid for medical care for the account beneficiary, their spouse, and dependents not covered by insurance. SEC. 103 increases the dollar limitation. SEC. 102 amends the definition of 'qualified medical expenses' in the Internal Revenue Code to include amounts paid for medical care for the account beneficiary, their spouse, and dependents not covered by insurance. SEC. 103 increases the dollar limitation to $8,000 ($16,000 for joint returns) for Medicare eligible individuals. Amendments are made to subsection (b) of the Code to adjust the limitations for taxable years. The subsection specifies the taxable year benefits for individuals under the Social Security Act. The cost-of-living adjustment is determined for subsequent years. The cost-of-living adjustment for taxable year benefits under the Social Security Act is determined for subsequent years by substituting 'calendar year 2009' for 'calendar year 1992'. The amendments made by this title will apply to taxable years starting after the enactment of this Act. Termination of existing health-related tax preferences for medical coverage and care is outlined in Title II. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding accident and health plans will not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. Contributions by employers to such plans will also not apply after this date. The Health Savings Account Expansion Act of 2009 amends the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years after 2009, with special rules for self-employed individuals and termination of certain medical expenses after December 31, 2009. SEC. 202. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYER DEDUCTION FOR HEALTH COVERAGE. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 denies employers a deduction for medical care expenses incurred for employees, spouses, and dependents under various healthcare arrangements. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009.
